evolution_stages.conversation_summary: 1) Gregory's fear of networking/procrastination manifested as overthinking an email to Professor Chen and delaying sending it. 2) Solutions offered/accepted: Coach provided a proven email template, 2-minute send timer, distraction techniques (fail compilations), and low-prep academic engagement (abstract skimming/wallpaper hack). 3) Student's response: Initially resistant ('Fine, I'll blame you'), but sent the email, skimmed the abstract, and used humor to cope. 4) Evidence of progress: EMAIL SENT, abstract reviewed (3 paragraphs + highlighted line), self-aware recognition of patterns ('Accidentally competent'), and creation of actionable next steps (5-day bump reminder).

Discussed Gregory's networking anxiety (emailing professors) and procrastination. Solutions offered: 1) Email template with 80% response guarantee, 2) 2-minute send rule, 3) Post-send rituals (victory lap/distraction), 4) Phone-free breaks. Gregory accepted all: sent email to Prof. Chen, froze phone to avoid refreshing, proposed 'Frozen Phone Fridays' to RA, and engaged with research abstracts using fail-video rewards. Progress evidenced by completed email send, implemented anxiety hacks, and humorous engagement with solutions ('Accidentally Competent' headline consideration).

evolution_stages.conversation_summary: Conversation analysis unavailable - fallback materialization used

1) Problems: Gregory's networking anxiety (avoiding emails/events) and procrastination (over-editing/delaying tasks) blocked research opportunities. 2) Solutions: Coach provided email templates, 2-minute rule, post-send rituals, and unconventional networking tactics (fry-truck approach). 3) Response: Gregory implemented email template, froze phone to limit checking, created fry-based networking, and drafted wellness event proposal. 4) Progress: Sent research email despite panic, developed 'Peer-Reviewed Fry Journal' to engage labs, transformed avoidance into action (frozen phone → campus initiative), and demonstrated behavioral adaptation (delaying → task completion).
